content:
The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" establishes the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, defining key terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area and Secretary of the Interior. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior to decrease fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. Projects will be developed to mitigate impacts on fisheries caused by water diversions in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to reduce fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. Eligible projects include developing fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features agreed upon by stakeholders. The Secretary will prioritize projects with a total cost of less than $5,000,000. SEC. 4. PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM. Non-Federal participation is voluntary, and the Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they apply to participate. Federal expenditures for projects on U.S. land or facilities are nonreimbursable. SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECTS. Evaluation and prioritization of projects under the Program is based on benefits to native fish species, size and type of water diversion, availability of funding sources, cost effectiveness, and additional opportunities for biological or water delivery system benefits. Eligibility requirements are also outlined. Eligibility requirements for projects under the Program include meeting Secretary and State requirements, as well as approval from all relevant Federal and non-Federal entities. The Secretary will consult with various agencies and utilize available data to determine project eligibility. Non-Federal participants in projects under the Program on non-government-owned land must provide 35% of the development costs and all necessary resources. The value of their contributions will be credited towards their cost share. Additional responsibilities may apply for non-Federal participants in such projects. Non-Federal participants on non-government-owned land must cover costs for operating, maintaining, and replacing the project. The Federal Government is responsible for these costs on Federal land or at a Federal facility. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from other sources for the same purpose. 

SEC. 9. REPORT. After three fiscal years, the Secretary must report to Congress on completed projects, those to be completed with remaining funds, and recommended Program changes based on project outcomes.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2001-2005. Limitations include not more than 25% of funds for projects in a single state, with a waiver option, and a cap of 6% for federal administrative expenses. The curr_chunk can be summarized as:
